newsitem.title: JAPAN: India to allow foreign-owned atomic plants - report.
newsitem.headline: India to allow foreign-owned atomic plants - report.

text.p: India will allow 100 percent foreign ownership of nuclear power plants in order to develop its infrastructure, Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda was quoted as saying in a Japanese business newspaper report on Saturday.
Gowda, in an interview in New Delhi on Friday with the Nihon Keizai Shimbun business daily, said full foreign ownership of a nuclear power plant in India would present no problem.
The Japanese translation of his statement quoted him as saying that "the 100 percent participation of foreign capital in nuclear power plants will be recognised... there is no problem whatsoever".
The front-page article provided no details on specific projects or schedules, however.

A decision to allow full foreign ownership of a nuclear power plant represents a sharp departure from the go-it-alone approach India has taken in building the nine atomic plants it now operates, the newspaper said.

However, India's refusal to join the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty and other international protocols aimed at curbing the spread of nuclear weapons would likely pose a barrier to the introduction of foreign nuclear technology in the country, the report said.
